dc:title: Resource edibility and the effects of predators and productivity on the outcome of trophic interactions
dc:creator: Leibold M.
dc:description: Population regulation of organisms is frequently viewed as being either by predation ("top-down' regulation) or by resource productivity ("bottom-up' regulation). These 2 types of regulation should ultimately balance, and the abundances of interacting organisms that result in any given environment should depend on the densities that can satisfy the balancing conditions. A simple model examines interactions among consumers and 7 types of resources that differ in edibility, and predicts that the effects of predation and productivity will depend strongly on the diet breadth of the consumers. Predictions are tested on the plankton of an oligotrophic lake by manipulating fish predation and nutrient productivity. Results are compared with those of 46 other similar experiments. The effects of predators and nutrients on consumers (zooplankton) and resources (phytoplankton) predicted by the model differ when the consumer assemblage is dominated by a generalist herbivore (Daphnia) from those expected in the absence of such a generalist herbivore. -from Author

dc:title: Alternative dynamic regimes for canopy-forming kelp: a variant on density-vague population regulation
dc:creator: Nisbet R.
dc:description: Develops a family of models for canopy-forming marine plants, based on the idea that recruitment can occur under appropriate conditions of temperature, bottom irradiance, and other unknown or unpredictable factors represented through a two-state birth-and-death process. In a constant environment, one can obtain a stable equilibrium set by the level of adult mortality, or can obtain a limit cycle about that population density for which self-shading is sufficiently strong to inhibit recruitment. Seasonal variation in temperature or average daily irradiance may have no effect, may cause complex patterns of multiyear cycles with no recruitment in certain years. Stochastic effects, which in the model act to further interrupt recruitment, may enhance the likelihood of multiyear fluctuations. The models predict cycle periods of the same order (3-5 yr) as have been observed in some natural populations of giant kelp Macrocystis pyrifera. With higher mortality rates and strong seasonal forcing, the model predicts annual bursts of recruitment. -from Authors

dc:title: Temporal patterns in species' abundances that imply a balance between competition and predation
dc:creator: Glasser J.W.
dc:description: Biological explanations for lognormal distributions of species' abundance are unnecessary. Moreover, this null model predicts an inverse relation between the number of species and the evenness of their frequencies, whereas the opposite occurs in nature. Observations for which hypothetical mechanicms of resource partitioning are approprate led to a simultaneous-breakage analogy that is equivalent to a more plausible sequential one in which the probabilities of segments' being broken vary directly with their lengths. One such mechanism, which accounts for successional dynamics in several natural communities, is outlined, and precise predictions are derived therefrom. -Author

dc:title: Adaptive variation in environmental sex determination in a nematode
dc:creator: Blackmore M.
dc:description: Provides the first evidence of adaptive variation in the expression of environmental sex determination (ESD) in a spatially patchy environment. A nematode parasite of mosquito larvae shows ESD with respect to growth opportunities for immatures. Within a population, hosts that allow larger growth produce mostly females; the converse, males. However, in populations with better overall growth opportunities (ie the emerging worms are larger on the average), the worm size at the shift from male to female is itself larger. This between-population adjustment of the threshold size is as predicted by adaptive-sex-ratio theory. -from Authors

dc:title: Selection on clutch size in birds
dc:creator: Price T.
dc:description: In bird populations, it is commonly observed that 1) clutch size is positively correlated with the number of surviving young a clutch produces and 2) the most productive clutch size is higher than the average clutch size. Such patterns are inevitable if females in different health or nutritional states vary in both the number of eggs they lay and the number of chicks they raise. A persistent selection differential for clutch size is expected at evolutionary equilibrium, even if clutch size is heritable. -from Authors

dc:title: Population dynamics and parasitic castration: test of a model
dc:creator: Blower S.
dc:description: Qualitative testable predictions in terms of population parameters were developed from a mathematical model for a specific marine host-parasite castration system. The model appears to describe the differences in the degree of parasitism among host species at each of 3 sites and to describe the biogeographic pattern of parasitism by the epicarid isopod Hemioniscus balani in the barnacle Chthamalus dalli along the West Coast of North America. Six of 6 predictions were substantiated with field data. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography and dispersal patterns of a tamarin population: possible causes of delayed breeding
dc:creator: Goldizen A.
dc:description: Saddle-back tamarins Saguinus fuscicollis in Peru live in small groups with 1 reproductive female and 1-2 breeding males. Most animals do not first breed for at least 1yr past the age of potential sexual maturity. Data on survival of adults and lengths of tenure of breeders suggest that breeding vacancies are not frequent. Emigration and survival patterns are not significantly different for the sexes. Delayed first breeding may occur in this species for any or all of the following reasons: a shortage of breeding positions, territories, or helpers; the risks of solitary dispersal; and the inclusive fitness benefits gained from helping. -from Authors

dc:title: Desert lizard diversity: additional comments and some data
dc:creator: Pianka E.
dc:description: A complex mega-hypothesis invoking multiple causality has been proposed to explain the high diversity of lizards in arid Australia (Morton & James 1988; see 89L/07344). Putative causal links in its intricate scheme are evaluated, and data are presented that can be brought to bear on the problem. Evidence that Australian soils are infertile is less than compelling. Chenopod-shrubs sites do not necessarily support impoverished termite faunas. Termites dominate the diets of Kalahari lizards and appear to be more abundant in the Kalahari semi-desert than in Australian deserts. A greater percentage of lizard species specialize on termites in the Kalahari than in Australia. A fire-succession cycle is quite important in spinifex habitats in Australia, generating a mosaic of habitats with differing degrees of openness at various post-fire ages; this greatly enhances lizard diversity. Fires may reticulate more in inland Australia than in grassland regions in other parts of the world. Fires, and fire-generated spatial heterogeneity, should be added to the list of physical factors driving the desert-lizard system. Historical and biogeographic phenomena must be better integrated into attempts to explain differences in diversity between geographical regions. -from Author

dc:title: Nonlethal injury to organisms as a mechanism of population regulation
dc:creator: Harris R.
dc:description: Nonlethal injury and the loss of body parts, including autotomy, caused by intraspecific and interspecific contact can adversely affect survival and reproduction until regeneration occurs. Rate of injury is likely to be positively related to prey density. Two models that capture these features predict that the susceptible population comes to a stable equilibrium if nonlethal injury reduces survival or reproduction or both. If injury is caused by another species, then the growth rate of the predator population must be coupled to prey density (and, hence, to the amount of injury) for stability to occur. In some salamanders, tail loss prevents reproduction and may explain observed population-size stability and the occurrence of reproductive and nonreproductive components in the population. In general, the injury models predict stable population dynamics, whereas the dynamically similar Lotka-Volterra predation model is less table. Nonlethal injury may play an important role in the regulatory biology of population size in many species. -from Author

dc:title: Molecular evolution and polymorphism: SAS-CFF meets the mutational landscape
dc:creator: Gillespie J.
dc:description: A Markov model of molecular evolution resulting from natural selection in a fluctuating environment that appears to be in substantial agreement with many of the observations on genetic variation within and between species is described. Although the Markov model is based on a particular model of selection, the Stochastic Additive Scale-Concave Fitness Function model, the approach (which uses strong-selection, weak-mutuation limits) suggests a general strategy for approximating the dynamics of a much broader class of models. The main dynamic features of the model are a rapid buildup phase that introduces new alleles into the population, an allelic-exchange phase that slowly replaces polymorphic alleles, and allelic constrictions, rare events that cause a complete turnover of alleles. The model exhibits many properties commonly observed in sequence data, among which are the variability of rates of evolution, the frequency spectrum of segregating sites, and the generation-time effect. -Author

dc:title: Population genetic structure and social evolution in the sphecid wasp Microstigmus comes
dc:creator: Ross K.
dc:description: No higher-level genetic structure was discernible at the level of the subpopulation, and microgeographic structure at the level of the local deme or individual host palm was, at most, modest. In contrast, genetic structure at the level of the individual nest was striking, with the average genetic relatedness among female nest mates estimated to be 0.62-0.67. This high relatedness results from the fact that colonies comprise relatively simple families, which are, in many instances, matrifilial monogynous societies. High relatedness among female nest mates and the absence of conspicious higher-level structure, in conjunction with the observed female-biased sex-investment ratios, are compatible with the interpretation that kin selection has played a major role in the origin of eusocial behavior in the recent ancestors of this wasp. The inferred colony composition and social organization further suggests that this social evolution may have occurred via a subtropical route, with simple matrifilial families rather than polygynous groups serving as the principal setting for the development of worker altruism. -from Authors

dc:title: Search modes of birds and lizards: evidence for alternative movement patterns
dc:creator: McLaughlin R.
dc:description: Predators may been seen as either "sit-and-wait foragers' or "active searchers'; these search strategies correlate with syndromes of behavioral, physiological and morphological traits (the syndrome hypothesis). Move-frequency data (moves per minute) for 58 species of forest birds and 22 species of lizards demonstrate that the move-frequency distributions of these 2 predator types are bimodal. Hence the dichotomous view of predator search strategies is realistic but there is variation within the 2 basic movement patterns. The author demonstrates that move frequency is a good descriptor of search mode; argues that the approach used in this interspecific analysis can be employed intraspecifically to determine whether predators switch search tactics; suggests that the degree to which physiology and morphology limit a predator's ability to switch modes can be examined by comparing intraspecific move-frequency distributions against the interspecific distributions provided here; and provides 2 hypotheses for the bimodality observed in the move-frequency distributions of birds and lizards. -from Author

dc:title: Iterated prisoner's dilemma: an approach to evolutionarily stable cooperation
dc:creator: Lima S.
dc:description: Develops a simple approach to evolutionarily stable cooperation in an iterated prisoner's-dilemma game that may yield stable cooperation over a wide range of conditions. Strategies for stable cooperation such as tit-for-tat (TFT) represent attempts to remove altruism from apparent cooperation; such attempts place cooperation wholly within the self-interest of the players in an effort to achieve stability. Stable cooperation in the iterated prisoner's dilemma this requires that the players are actually not caught in the dilemma. A way is explored to achieve this end by considering a situation in which the fitness of one player depends explictly on the fitness it allows the other player via its own actions. The "mutual dependencies' depicted here are probably common in the actual payoff structure of iterated games; thus, apparent cooperation in social animals may not necessarily reflect a TFT-like strategy. -from Author

dc:title: A sexual-selection model for the evolution of imitative learning of song in polygynous birds
dc:creator: Aoki K.
dc:description: Although normal song development in oscines depends on imitative learning, it presumably was innately determined (directly inherited, nonmodifiable) in the ancestral species. Evolution of imitative song from innate song is investigated theoretically, using a genetic model of sexual selection by female choice in a polygynous population. Since song is usually limited to sexually mature males and since females exhibited preferences with respect to various aspects of song, sexual selection may well have been involved. Specifically, it is assumed that imitative learning may give rise to a variant song that some females prefer over innate song and also that female preference is not affected by early song experience. However, the assumption of polygyny restricts the applicability of results, since most bird species are monogamous. Coevolution of imitative song and female preference from low initial frequencies requires a strong preference. Transmission from father to son is critical and must be efficient, unless compensated for by strong female preference. Initial increase of imitative song is less likely to occur if paternal song is forgotten and replaced by a new song learned from another adult male. These predictions may be difficult to reconcile with the assumption of polygyny, which may imply limited opportunity for interaction between father and son. -from Author

dc:title: Monodominant and species-rich forests of the humid tropics: causes for their co-occurrence
dc:creator: Hart T.B.
dc:description: A study of the structure and floristics at a transition zone from a monodominant to a more diverse forest in the African humid tropics, Ituri Forest, Zaire, was conducted to elucidate the mechanisms maintaining floristic diversity and the discontinuity between mixed forests and forests dominated by a single tree species (monodominant). The mixed forest's greater diversity could not be explained by substrate differences, greater maturity, or greater predation on seeds or juveniles. The dominant species of the monodominant forest was shade-tolerant and had poorly dispersed seeds. Tree species associated with the dominant were also found in the mixed forest. Monodominant and mixed forests also occur side by side in the Asian and American tropics. As in the African example, many of these monodominant forests share most species with neighboring mixed forests. Characteristically, the dominant species have large seeds and shade-tolerant seedlings. Monodominant tropical forests are widespread and may indicate areas that have not experienced large-scale disturbance for long periods. -from Authors

dc:title: Anti-herbivory chemical defense in plants: a note on the concept of cost
dc:creator: Fagerstrom T.
dc:description: We still lack a precise, general definition of the cost concept that has ecological as well as evolutionary meaning while retaining its physiological relevance. Such a definition is proposed with a demonstration of how it can be applied to various questions. Cost should be expressed as a loss in relative growth rate of somatic tissue, but extended to include turnover and recirculation of defensive substances. The analysis is confined to the case of exponential growth for 3 reasons: 1) when cost is expressed in terms of lost growth rate, it is implicit that the plant should be in a phase of active growth (eg, pre-reproductive phase), a phase in which exponential growth is often a good approximation of the real growth pattern; 2) single integrated physiological units may often grow exponentially even if the whole plant has ceased to do so; and 3) exponential growth is the only nontrivial case for which simple analytical solutions can be found to the kinetic equations used. -from Author

dc:title: Sperm competition in the thirteen-lined ground squirrel: differential fertilization success under field conditions
dc:creator: Foltz D.
dc:description: Collected mating-history data on >40 estrous females Spermophilus tridecemlineatus in a population on the outskirts of Norman, Oklahoma. In most cases, females simply copulate with any and all males that approach and attempt to mate. This study confirms that the sperm competition experienced by males produces patterns of differential fertilization that are correlated with mating order. -from Authors

dc:title: The ecology of Hawaiian flower-breeding drosophilids. 2. Adult dispersions and reproductive ecology
dc:creator: Montague J.
dc:description: Hawaiian flower-breeding Scaptomyza caliginosa and their host morning glories Ipomoea acuminata were examined in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Kilauea, Hawaii. Males tend to overdisperse; females tend to aggregate. Densities of adults per blossom were high in sunlit than in shaded blossoms, but female reproductive effort (eggs per female per blossom) was higher in shaded blossoms. Variation in female reproductive effort did not correlate with variation in either temperature or humidity in the field. Male courtship behavior has an inhibitory effect on oviposition within crowded blossoms. This finding may represent a density-dependent component in the maintenance of the low fecundity of this species. -from Author

dc:title: The cost of tundra plant structures: evaluation of concepts and currencies
dc:creator: Chapin F.
dc:description: Carbon costs of synthesis are quite similar among parts and species of tundra plants and among chaparral shrubs, because all plant parts have substantial concentrations of certain energetically expensive constituents (either lignin or protein and tannin). Evidence did not support the generalization that evergreen leaves are more expensive to produce than deciduous leaves. Initial N and P costs of synthesis differ substantially among plant parts and species. These costs are higher in leaves than in stems and tend to decrease from deciduous shrubs and forbs to graminoids to evergreen shrubs to mosses to lichens. Nutrient costs also vary substantially among species within a growth form. Final N and P costs are much less than initial costs because of resorption from senescing parts, whereas final carbon costs are not greatly modified by resorption. Carbon and nutrient costs are interconvertible, if their exchange ratios are known, but if exchange ratios are not known (usually the case) carbon may in general by a more practical currency than nutrients for estimating the cost of synthesis. Nutrients may be the more useful currency in evaluating the cost of synthesis. Nutrients may be the more useful currency in evaluating the cost of tissue removal by herbivores and pathogens and tissue investment in reproduction, particularly under conditions of strong nutrient limitation. -from Authors

dc:title: The habitat volumes of scarce and ubiquitous plants: a test of the model of environmental control
dc:creator: Burgman M.
dc:description: Examined the expected relationship between the ubiquity of species in samples and the realized edaphic habitat volumes of these species. The habitat space of a suite of plants from southern Western Australia was defined by principal-components analysis of soil data. The habitat volumes of 36 scarce and 41 ubiquitous species were not significantly different. An alternative hypothesis is suggested, that scarce plants do not have restricted environmental tolerances but, rather, fill their habitat space more sparsely. Strong correlations between species frequencies in samples and habitat volume were observed in the total data set and in 8 of 10 plant guilds, corroborating predictions, but only half the correlations within guilds were significant at the 5% level when statistical bias from sampling frequency was taken into account. -from Author

dc:title: Facultative placentotrophy and the evolution of squamate placentation: quality of eggs and neonates in Virginia striatula
dc:creator: Stewart J.
dc:description: Newborn size in the viviparous snake Virginia striatula is determined by female size, egg size, and placental nourishment and is correlated inversely with current fecundity. Of the 2 modes of embryonic nutrition used, lecithotrophy and placentotrophy, an increase in vitellogenic nourishment results in a reduction in current fecundity, whereas placental nourishment does not affect current fecundity. Newborn composition is determined by 2 mechanisms: one is correlated with female size, the other regulated by the developing embryo. -from Author

dc:title: The latitudinal gradient in geographical range: how so many species coexist in the tropics
dc:creator: Stevens G.
dc:description: The latitudinal gradient in species richness is paralleled by a latitudinal gradient in geographical-range size called Rapoport's rule. The greater annual range of climatic conditions to which individuals in high-latitude environments are exposed relative to what low-latitude organisms face may have favored the evolution of broad climatic tolerances in high-latitude species. This broad tolerance of individuals from high latitudes has led to wider latitudinal extent in the geographical range of high-latitude species than of lower-latitude species. If low-latitude species typically have narrower environmental tolerances than high-latitude species, then equal dispersal abilities in the 2 groups would place more tropical organisms out of their preferred habitat than higher-latitude species out of their preferred habitat. A larger number of "accidentals' (species that are poorly suited for the habitat) would thus occur in tropical assemblages. The constant input of these accidentals artificially inflates species numbers and inhibits competitive exclusion. -from Author

dc:title: Chromosomal influences on life-history variation along an altitudinal transect in Drosophila robusta
dc:creator: Etges W.
dc:description: Life-history variation was associated with the inversion polymorphisms on 3 of 5 of the chromosomal arms in Drosophila robusta. Karyotypic differences were associated with variation in egg-to-adult developmental time (DEVT), age at first reproduction, and early fecundity, but not adult longevity. Variations in DEVT among gene arrangements on the left arm of the second chromosome were change by temperature, but consistently across populations. Some low-elevation karyotypes were associated with shorter DEVT in warmer-temperature conditions. Third-chromosome karyotypes were also associated with differences in DEVT, but in a population-specific way, indicating variation in genic contents of third-chromosome gene arrangements among populations along this elevational transect. Third-chromosome gene arrangements were also associated with correlated sets of fitness characters. Differences in DEVT were correlated with clinal variation in second-chromosome gene arrangements. Changes in inversion frequencies through time may influence the course of life-history evolution for inversions with genic contents that are relatively uniform from population to population. -from Author

dc:title: The interspecific size-density relationship among crowded plant stands and its implications for the -3/2 power rule of self- thinning
dc:creator: Weller D.
dc:description: Presents a geometric model that explains the interspecific size-density relationship among crowded plant stands in terms of 2 descriptors of the volume occupied by an average individual in each stand: density of biomass per unit of occupied volume and ratio of height to base width. The model predicts that stand measurements form a linear band when the logarithm of aboveground stand biomass is plotted against the logarithm of plant density. The band appears narrow because biomass per unit of volume and the ratio of height to width are biologically constrained and vary much less than stand biomass or density. In the absence of systematic trends in either parameter, simple geometry would fix the slope of the band at - 1/2 . Thus, the extent of deviation from - 1/2 is of primary biological interest, since that deviation reflects biological trends in plant shape or packing density across the plant kingdom. Aboveground biomass, density, and height data from 370 plant stands revealed systematic trends in both parameters. Small plants growing at high densities tend to be relatively more slender and to pack more biomass per unit of volume than do larger plants in less dense stands. Herbaceous monocots are more slender and pack more biomass per unit of volume than herbaceous dicots, which are in turn higher in both measures than trees. Such trends yield an interspecific relationship with a slope shallower than the ideal - 1/2 value. The interspecific band encloses dynamic self-thinning lines that differ widely in slope; therefore, the static and dynamic relationships can be considered independently and are not simple facets of a single thinning "law'. Many proposed interpretations of the constant in the dynamic self-thinning equation can be more clearly applied to a new constant calculated for single stands from the product of biomass per unit of volume and the ratio of height to width. -from Author

dc:title: Marriage entrapment by "solitary' mothers: a study on male deception by female pied flycatchers
dc:creator: Gjershaug J.
dc:description: By soliciting copulations, widowed female Ficedula hypoleuca may have led the new males to believe that they were the fathers of their broods. The new males were thus fooled or trapped, even though the females had already laid their eggs and were therefore temporarily infertile. -from Authors

dc:title: Coexistence on a seasonal resource
dc:creator: Brown J.
dc:description: A model is presented giving conditions for competitive coexistence on a single resource with seasonal productivity. It is assumed that individuals can allocate time to foraging and remaining dormant and that dormancy is less costly than foraging. Coexistence requires a trade-off between foraging and maintenance efficiency. The species with the higher maintenance efficiency (ratio of harvest rate to cost of dormancy) can exploit periods of high resource abundance and then inexpensively remain dormant during periods of low abundance. The species with the higher foraging efficiency (ratio of harvest rate to the additional cost of foraging over remaining dormant) can continue to exploit profitably periods of low resource abundance. The optimal behaviour of the foragers promotes coexistence, and increasing variation in resource productivity increases the chances of adding to the community a species with a higher maintenance efficiency but lower foraging efficiency. -from Author

dc:title: The distribution and abundance of resources encountered by a forager
dc:creator: Possingham H.P.
dc:description: A model of resource renewal and depletion is used to explore the relationship between the distribution and abundance of the resources encountered by a forager (encountered crop) and the distribution and abundance of resources observed by researchers (stainding crop). Unless the arrival rate of any forager at a patch is independent of previous arrivals at that patch, encountered crop does not equal standing crop. Pollination ecologists should be wary of using standing crop to measure encountered crop. When resources in a patch renew at a constant rate, systematic foraging (reducing the standard deviation but not the mean of the inter-arrival time) does not increase the mean resource abundance encountered by a forager. However, systematic foraging may increase the fitness of a territorial forager because it reduces mean standing crop and therefore intruder pressure, and systematic foraging may increase the fitness of a risk-averse forager because it reduces the standard deviation of encountered crop. When the rate of resource renewal in a patch depends on the amount of resource in that patch, systematic foraging alters the mean resource abundance encountered by a forager. In particular, when resources increase in a patch at a decreasing rate, systematic foraging increases mean encountered crop. -Author

dc:title: Interpretations and comparisons of constants in the species-area relationship: an additional caution
dc:creator: Lomolino M.
dc:description: The utility of the most comlmon model describing this relationship, the power model (S = cAz, where S is species richness, A is area, and c and z are fitted constants), is debatable. The strongest controversy stems not from the "fit' provided by this model, but from the biological relevance of its exponent, z. This paper re-emphasizes previous cautions on potential misinterpretation of z values and discusses a shortcoming of the power model that may overestimate its exponent, underestimate its coefficient, and thus compromise inferences derived from comparisons among archipelagoes or taxonomic groups. -from Author

dc:title: Sexual selection, natural section, and a fitness trade-off in a tropical frog with male parental care
dc:creator: Townsend D.
dc:description: In male Puerto Rican coqui Eleutherodactylus coqui 1) variance in relative mating success (opportunity for sexual selection) and variance in relative hatching success (opportunity for natural selection) both contribute substantially to total variance in male reproductive success; and 2) a negative interaction exists between these 2 components of male reproductive success. The negative interaction represents the existence of a significant fitness trade-off between mating success and hatching success for male coquies. -from Author

dc:title: Relationships among leaf construction cost, leaf longevity, and light environment in rain-forest plants of the genus Piper
dc:creator: Williams K.
dc:description: Among 7 Piper species characteristic of multiple stages of rain forest secondary succession, leaf construction cost increased and leaf longevity decreased as available light increased. When Piper species characteristic of different habitats co-occurred, their leaf construction costs were similar, but mean leaf construction costs for sun and shade species, based on plants sampled from the entire range of light environments, were quite different. The hypothesis is rejected that leaf construction cost and leaf longevity are generally positively related. The arguments previously used to support the hypothesis fail to consider carbon income as well as cost. The more general hypothesis, predicting a positive relationship between longevity and the ratio of cost to carbon gain, is conceptually more robust and consistent with the data. -from Authors

dc:title: The evolution of dioecy from distyly: reevaluation of the hypothesis of the loss of long-tongued pollinators
dc:creator: Muenchow G.
dc:description: Simulated the spread of gender-aborting alleles in a distylous population, allowing the contribution of the low flower parts to reproduction to be set at zero or at values above zero. Mistakes (the expression of gender-aborting alleles in the "wrong' morph) were allowed at a rate of or above zero. Evidence for the statements that pin plants evolved into females and thrums into males, and that ancestral tubular flowers evolved into shallow flowers, is reviewed. -from Authors

dc:title: The evolution of viviparity in amniote vertebrates: egg retention versus egg size reduction
dc:creator: Dunbrack R.
dc:description: Examines a recent explanation for the absence of viviparity in birds that depends heavily on a model that was developed to account for viviparity in squamate reptiles. The elevated body temperature of birds precludes extended egg retention, an early stage in the evolution of viviparity from an oviparous ancestor, probably through constraints on the rate of oxygen transfer to developing embryos. If the effects of endothermy are included in the model developed to account for the evolution of viviparity in reptiles, then qualitative and quantitative differences in embryonic developmental rates are predicted between reptiles and birds as a result of eggs being retained within the uterine environment. This modification offers an explanation for the total absence of viviparity in birds. The evolutionary sequence for mammalian viviparity from an endothercm viviparous ancestor was probably through the progressive production of smaller eggs, with proportionally shorter embryonic developmental times, which would allow for relatively longer periods of egg retention before oxygen-supply constraints would be reached. The critical characteristic allowing extensive egg size reduction in mammals was lactation, which allowed the feeding of tiny altricial neonates. -from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific brood raiding, territoriality, and slavery in ants
dc:creator: Pollock G.
dc:description: The possible role of intraspectific territoriality in the evolution of obligate interspecific slavery, dulosis, among ants has been debated by several authors. Recent research on the establishment of colonies in several non-dulotic, intraspecifically territorial ants provides support for and an extension of the territorial hypothesis as a general explanation for dulosis. Several ant species, regardless of dulotic tendencies, have clumped starting nests; adult colonies, nonetheless, are territorial, suggesting that, from each clump, at most a single adult colony will prevail. Territoriality among these starting colonies takes the form of reciprocal brood raiding ("intraspecific slavery'), colonies with the most workers, including those acquired from brood raiding, prevail. Truly dulotic species have polydomous hosts, ie a single colony occupies several nests. Such polydomous host colonies represent a renewable resource that likely permits specialization in their procurement without resource depletion, ie the evolution of obligate dulosis. -Authors

dc:title: Male and female reproductive success in the hermaphroditic plant Phlox drummondii
dc:creator: Schlichting C.
dc:description: Three sets of reciprocal crosses were performed among 12 plants of the hermaphroditic annual Phlox drummondii, a self-incompatible species. Each plant was used as both a pollen donor and a pollen recipient for estimating both male and female reproductive success. For each cross, pollen germinability, number of seeds produced, weight of each seed produced, and total weight of all seeds were measured. The performances of the 12 plants as females varied significantly for all traits measured for each set of crosses. Among the 12 plants as males, significant variation occurred only for the total seed weight in cross 1 and for the number of seeds and the total seed weight in cross 3. -from Authors
